ЁЯПЫя╕П
Pioneers of Dravidian Architecture

The Pallava dynasty, with its capital at Kanchipuram, laid the foundation for South Indian architecture. They evolved from rock-cut temples (Rathas) to structural temples. The Pancha Rathas and the Shore Temple at Mahabalipuram, built by Narasimhavarman I (Mamalla), are UNESCO World Heritage sites.

тЪФя╕П
Great Rivalry

During the reigns of Mahendravarman I and Narasimhavarman I, the Pallavas had a fierce conflict with the Badami Chalukyas (Pulakeshin II). Narasimhavarman defeated Pulakeshin, captured Vatapi, and took the title 'Vatapikonda'. This is one of the most famous rivalries in the history of South India.

ЁЯОн
Art and Literature

Pallava kings were scholars themselves. Mahendravarman I wrote the satirical play 'Mattavilasa Prahasana'. Great Sanskrit poets like Bharavi (Kiratarjuniya) and Dandin (Dashakumaracharita) adorned the Pallava court.
